Feels close to call but here is some insight from betting market. My poll-based model implies about 64/36 (probability, not % of votes) for Remain (some arbitrary parameters I admit). Betting markets imply 76/24 (these are based on liquid two way markets). More interestingly, I had a detailed look at markets by percentage. These are less liquid so there is some approximation but here are the current markets by band (votes for Remain): 0-40 1.9%, 40-45 3.4%, 45-50 16.2%, 50-52.5 13.9%, 52.5-54.5 19.8%, 54.5-55 4.9%, 55-56.5 14.4%, 56.5-60 12.4%. 60-65 9.0%, 65-70 2.5%, 70-100 1.3%. (Bands are not of equal width because I used different sources). What does this mean? Market doesn't think it's very close with high confidence (i.e. small difference, low variance), it thinks it's much in favour of Remain but with significant risk in both directions (significant difference but high variance). Density peaks at around 54% for Remain which is quite big and 60% appears more likely than 45%! We shall see who gets closer, polls or markets but I thought I'd share this for those who are looking for more detailed clues. All calculations are approximate, in good faith and used at your own risk.

By JAMES MACKINTOSH
Markets have fixated for the past week on whether Britain is about to vote to leave the European Union. Sterling, the euro, gold, global shares and even the yen have had synchronized swings as the prospects of such a “Brexit” rise and fall ahead of Thursday’s referendum.
Amid the speculation, little attention has been paid to the core assumptions investors are making. In particular, moves in sterling and in British government bonds, known as gilts, demonstrate a broad belief that the pound’s fall will be pronounced but not catastrophic, and that the Bank of England will ignore any imported inflation.
Investors mostly are brushing aside the prospect of a repeat. In the one sterling crash since the Bank of England gained operational independence over monetary policy in 1997—the post-Lehman depreciation when the pound fell by almost one-third—policy makers ignored the inflation which resulted. Instead, they cut interest rates to a record low, where they remain, to support the economy.
Sushil Wadhwani, a former Bank of England policy maker who runs a hedge fund, is concerned that after several years of stability a big fall in the pound could lead to more selling and feed on itself to create a sterling crisis. “This time round there’s a very good chance it becomes a vicious move [in the pound] at some stage because of the lack of hedging,” he said.

Lots of good quantitative information regarding key issues such as immigration is available. However, my basis for the increasing confidence in a remain vote mainly coming down to the realization that the real question is how the voters will vote, not "Do you think it makes more sense for the U.K. to remain in the E.U." Easy to answer the wrong question. As such, when given the choice I believe there is a human propensity for inaction versus taking explicit action. For staying a course versus changing course, particularly when the decision is complicated or confusing. The voters have expressed confusion over the campaigns of both sides and conflicting data. This belief would be consistent with the "do not knows" most likely siding with Remain as we get closer and making the difference in a close race. Additionally, social influencers like British novelist J.K. Rowling stand to have a meaningful impact on this undecided demographic. Increasing my forecast from 55% to 80%.  The polls breaking for Vote Leave was concerning and I down weighted from 65% to 55%.  I wrote last time that there was risk of circularity in ignoring the polls and looking at the betting odds, as the bookmakers were also ignoring the polls and all of us were looking at Scottish referendum as the playbook for how the vote would turn out.  The tragic death of Jo Cox has certainly placed Remain in the winning position, witnessed by the swing in the polls back to Remain after the weekend.  I also noted before that in a fairly large, self-confident country like the UK, political campaigns needed to balance hope and fear issues.  A fear-only campaign can work in Scotland but not in the UK as a whole.  The Leave camp had nostalgia of "sovereignty" and old empire and the fear of unlimited "immigration", while Remain was unbalanced with only the fear issue of "economy recession", however with this terrible event last week, I believe the Remain camp has been able to catalyse its positive message.  This has been confirmed by David Cameron recent positive stance as well as his tweet of Jo Cox's final op-ed about the benefits of EU immigration for the UK.  Considering this was an issue Remain would not try rebut but reassure in public, I sense they are more confident of the mood of the majority in the wake of her death.   There has been a blistering  critique in the pro Leave press about any the use of Ms Cox's name or death during the rest of the campaign, but politics is a messy business about messaging.   The Vote Remain camp would argue to ignore and blank out her death would be equally demeaning for what she had been campaigning for and what she stood for "pro-immigration" and "pro-EU".   In politics, seminal events matter.  The UK is a secular, liberal society in the large political "middle" and I assume that is where the undecideds live.  The undecideds should swing to Remain more decisively as the implicit, anti-minority principles of the right wing elements within the Leave Vote are highlighted more vigorously in the press.  There is also a crescendo of business leaders and groupings of scholars/"experts" like Noble Laureate economists' open letter coming out in the past few days for UK to stay in EU.   In addition and probably more important, publications like the Times and Economist which are typically critical of the EU have come out for Remain.  (I think Rupert Murdoch is hedging his bets).  What is interesting about this activity of the Remain supporters is that its all coming out nearer to the actual poll date whether by design or in reaction to the previous weak polls.  One forecaster wrote presciently when up weighting his forecast precisely when polls had swung to Leave, stating and I paraphrase, the weak polls for Remain will reinvigorate campaign and create a sense of urgency for voter turnout supporting Remain which was one of the significant risks, an apathetic voting block.

Revised down to nought: No, a majority of voters will elect to leave, not remain. The dreadful killing of Jo Cox has led to campaigning being suspended. When it resumes, we can expect both sides to be rather more muted and wish to appear as responsible citizens – the fear mongering on both sides will abate. I would predict that her funeral and memorial service will not take place before Monday 27 June, ie., after the referendum vote. The question is: how much of a difference will this make to the outcome? There will be an increase in turnout from political ‘moderates’ who will see their vote as being in defiance of violence; they might increase the ‘Remain’ vote. But will it be enough to allay fears on immigration and the economic risk of leaving (which ‘Leave’ voters see as positives)? I doubt it. Left wing voters who support ‘Leave’ also see this vote as a method of ‘punishing’ the Right, believing it will bring down the Prime Minister and his Chancellor, tear the Conservative Party apart and leaving them critically wounded for the next four years, as well as giving Labour a reason to change its Leader – in other words, Left-wing ‘Leave’ voters are considering far more than just our membership of the EU. Barring a further externality, ‘Leave’ has won. the vote will be split 53% Leave / 47% Remain.

Even when polls were indicating a clear lead for In, this was a difficult call. I have long thought that the probabilities implied by the bookies (around 75% less a month ago) were too optimistic for In. Polls are currently indicating a very close call, possibly a lead for Out. Some issues to consider. (1) The press, very relevant in the UK, has been on balance favouring Out, business press favouring In. I will skip the detail but what matters is press with impact on swing voters. The Times coming out in favour of In as it is rumoured will have more impact than those who cater for the die-hearts. (2) Uncertainty increased by the fact that (a) parties are unclear in their message and (b) are not necessarily listened to. Labour comes across as unconvincing In, Lib Dems are absent from everything and the Conservatives are facing long-brewing fundamental internal divisions across all demographic dimensions. (3) Polls in the last Elections proved v unreliable for reasons still unclear. In my view, Out supporters have been a lot more vocal recently, shifting the argument almost exclusively to Sovereignty and Immigration. In comparison, In supporters are typically more moderate and less vocal. (4) In has conducted a poor campaign, particularly recently but appears to have won the economic argument clearly, hence Out has shifted to the Sovereignty/Immigration issues. However, economic risks still matter to most in a more direct way. (5) Private polls no doubt are taking place and their impact is seen in the betting markets which are now broadly reflecting fair prices.

The trend recently seems to be to forecast down, but I'm more confident now than before that the UK will remain. Partly this is due to the impact of the Scottish and Northern Irish votes - both of which are heavily for remaining (part of the argument for staying in the UK was that Scotland would almost certainly be unable to rejoin the EU due to Spain's Catalonia concerns, and the Northern Irish border with Ireland would be negatively impacted by a spilt with the EU). William Hague (a consummate Eurosceptic) has spoken out in favour of remain with the argument that Cameron has dealt with future sovereignty issues with the EU already due to the pressure the UK gov was able to put on the EU over the threat of leaving. No new powers can be imposed without a vote of the British people, and the UK has been able to opt-out of things like the refugee quotas that are plaguing the rest of Europe. Add this to the tendency to vote the status quo, and the result will be remain.

I am reducing my forecast from 66%.  Looking at the forecasters here and the bookmakers, I suspect there could be risks of group think and circularity in the decision process.  Three important factors are raised consistently as a basis for this groups' forecasts to get to the average 70% probability, 1) the polls are not reliable, 2) the betting market is more reliable, and 3) the Scottish referendum.  Firstly I would make the assumption that polling methodologies have been improved since the Scottish and National election failures.  Secondly, the betting market is probably using the same factors we are using, polls are unreliable and Scottish referendum turned to No vote at the polling station, while late polls were signalling a surging Yes.  There is a lot of recency bias here.   But these are two different referendums with different hopes and fears.  I think it may be worthwhile weighing up the hopes over fears for Brexit.  Sovereignty and Immigration are the main hope and fear factors for the Leave campaign and economic deep recession is the fear factor for Remain.  The Remain campaign's biggest drawback is that neither Cameron nor Corbyn are true EU believers, so the campaign lacks that balance.  Unlike the Scottish referendum where Cameron government and the EU played hardball and stoked sufficient fear with Scottish and their small economy, the UK is a large economy and surely more confident in face of the risks and fears of the Remain campaign.  The UK also has a political and cultural history of "Splendid Isolation" from continental Europe and its affairs.  It helps being an island.  In conclusion I do think the polls may be more accurate this time and I do believe it will be a tighter contest than Scottish referendum.  The tendency of undecided people veering to the status quo at the polling station takes me to above 50% probability.

COMMENT: I was quite sure that from now on a stream of bad case scenarios if leaving the EU would be in the press.

With online polls (like YouGov's) tending to show a narrow lead for 'Leave', while telephone polls mostly show a narrow lead for 'Remain', public opinion seems finely balanced, and turnout is clearly going to be critical. There are two key forces to weigh up, where turnout is concerned: 'Leave' voters have a much higher average age, and we know older voters are much more likely to turn out to vote. But 'Remain' voters have a much higher average education level ('Remain' has a 30% lead among university graduates), and more educated voters are *also* more likely to turn out. According to Anthony Wells of YouGov, these two forces roughly cancel out. So with finely balanced public opinion, and little to guide us in terms of turnout, why am I 75% certain that 'remain' will win? My answer in three words: "status quo bias." We saw in the Scottish Independence referendum that undecided voters broke for 'Remain' at a disproportionate rate. So if the 12% of voters currently self-reporting as 'undecided' prove equally likely to prefer the status quo, that should be enough to tip the balance in favour of remain.

Both sides have been producing implausible scenarios, but the Leave group seems to be putting forward particularly weak arguments; every voter must know by now that their Â£350 million a week saving is wrong, but they keep using this same wrong figure, they also know that Turkey will not be joining the EU in the next 4 years (if ever) so their credibility is evaporating. On the other hand I doubt that many people are convinced by the Remain claim that house prices will be 10% to 18% lower after a Brexit. In the last week the polls - in particular the telephone polls - (and betting odds) seem to be moving towards Remain (as many people suspected it would).

Once again, a problem caused by the wording of the question:  In elections that are controversial or involve lots of people who can't decide, spoilt ballots are not uncommon.  If Stay pulls 49.9% and Leave pulls 49.8% and .3% of ballots are spoilt, Stay will win, which is what I suppose to have been the intent of the Q, since the outcome and not the margin is what has policy implications.  However, "a majority of voters" will not have supported it.  As it happens, that is precisely the proportion of spoilt ballots in 2015. In 2010, about 1% were spoilt.  In an election with only two choices, this can be critical indeed.

The GJ consensus forecast has started to climb, largely on reports of recent polling data[1]. Color me *a little* skeptical though. The average of the 12 (12!) polls taken in April (as reported by "The Financial Times"[2]) shows less than a 2% gap between thems that wants to stay and thems that don't: 42.75% = "stay" and 40.83% = "go." Of course that leaves 14.59% who haven't made up their minds. If you assume that the undecided won't break in large numbers for either of "stay" or "go" (and I don't know of any evidence that counts strongly against this assumption), then "stay" gets 51.1% of the vote, and "go" gets 48.8%, with a standard deviation of a little more than 4%. That gives us about a 61% chance of "stay" winning, and that seems too close for comfort.

Leaving an economic union like the EU is a pretty rare occurrence, and very rare for a large stable country like the EU. The only examples of countries actually leaving the EU (actually its predecessor the EEA) are Algeria, which declared independence from France, Greenland, which remains a dependency of Denmark which is a member of the EU, and Saint Barthelemy an overseas department of the French government. None of these are even remotely comparable to the UK. OPEC has had some defections although OPEC is not an economic community in the way the UK is, most defectors have returned, and generally the defectors are weak nations that feel they are not getting much benefit from OPEC despite paying large fees. Other examples of states/Economic union break ups seem to be rooted in ethnic struggle, which is not something we are seeing with the UK. Thus, there is limited historical precedent for an event like this. 
The EU has a long history of euro-skepticism in government that ultimately gets shot down. In 1974 the ascendant Labour government had campaigned on a promise to hold a referendum on EEC accession. The ensuing debate looked remarkably similar to today’s debate. The Labour cabinet was split on supporting remain vs leave. Ultimately a new agreement with the EEC was reached and, in the first nationwide referendum ever, the British people overwhelmingly voted to remain a part of the EEC. Certainly Britain’s economic position relative to the rest of Europe was a bit different in 1974 than today but it is interesting that the tone and nature of the arguments seems to be so similar. 
There are three things that have me concerned as I watch this:
1)	Polling credibility. After both the Scottish referendum and the 2015 Parliamentary elections polling in the UK was more or less shredded from a credibility perspective. For one, they were flat wrong, and two there were significant differences between online and phone polling. It will be essential to monitor the volatility of these series and their direction going forward. 
2)	The arguments being posed by both sides are not salient to real voters. The Remain campaign’s website has a few snippets with limited additional factual evidence. There is a seemingly credible element about the true “cost” from a dollars and cents (I know they don’t use dollars) perspective to leaving the trade union and how it would hit the pocket books of consumers, otherwise it is pretty weak. The leave campaign, while disorganized, has arguments that a much more salient for individual voters. I am also having trouble reconciling some of this trade stuff. Goods trade appears to be covered by the WTO and remain campaigners suggest that services will not be covered, but as signatories to the GATT the UK and EU are signatories to GATS as well. So how will single market access for services be affected? 
3)	My small sample of Londoners amongst whom I have conducted my own non-scientific polling are all pretty pessimistic. The most common line of reasoning I hear is “If you were the UK today would you vote to join?” that’s a red herring but people don’t seem to care. 
The Remain campaign is going to have to convince the undecided voters to vote to remain in order to secure victory. I think that there will be some moderate success there but current polling seems to be pretty clearly signaling remain. I think that the volatility of the current polling, although they may be somewhat unreliable, is what will drive my forecast going forward.

Polls suggest this is near a 50:50 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum). This reminds me of the Scottish referendum, where the campaign to leave is emotional and exciting, whereas the campaign to stay is dull and threatening. All the 'characters' are on the anti-EU side. The media is largely anti-EU. Half the Tory party is anti-EU. Both leaders of the Tories and Labour have at best luke-warm support for the EU. London a key pro-EU voting area, has just seen Boris Johnson come out against the EU (where he is very popular despite the city being fairly liberal).  The pro-EU groups - liberals, and Blairite labour, have essentially been completely eliminated from contemporary British politics, so will have limited influence. The Scots are pro-EU, but this could backfire, if southern English conservatives see the EU as a something the Scottish like, so therefore they should dislike it on principle. A similar problem lies for the business lobby, in that big business is pro-EU, however, again if it pushes too hard it would be seen as 'interfering' in the people's will - big business is not popular in the UK. Small businesses are less involved in foreign trade, so will vote more in line with general cultural views on the referendum, rather than being a pro-lobby so to speak. A few key pro-EU voting groups will also be excluded or minimised from the elections. Ex-pat Brits, who you would assume are generally more pro-EU, especially those living in the EU, are not allowed to vote in the if they have lived away from it for more than 15 years, whilst those who legally are still allowed to vote will find it extremely difficult. Voting from abroad in UK elections is very difficult. Similarly, another more pro-EU group would be young people, students and young professionals.  Most don't live in owned-properties, and instead rent, and move regularly, making it more difficult to register to vote, so tend to have lower voting statistics. It is actually difficult to come up with reasons why the stay campaign would win, other than in general people don't like to vote for change.

"Britain is the only country among the large member states that has both a low score on structural cohesion and a low score on individual cohesion. I doubt I have differentiated insight on this issue, but I think it's too close to call. My hypothesis is that EU membership is generally preferred by elites (a term I use descriptively, not as a value judgment) whose jobs directly or indirectly benefit from EU membership and/or who care about abstractions like standing in the international community. If this is true, the implication seems to me that it will be easier to marshal resources in favor of "yes" than "no." However, there is clearly a trend among non-elites in Western democracies to vote against what they perceive as elite priorities or candidates (e.g. Trump, Le Pen, etc.) regardless of the implications. I think this creates a practical difficulty for a "yes" campaign--the benefits of EU membership are diffuse and it is not obvious (to me) to what extent they accrue to non-elites, so how will this be sold? External shocks, if they happen, seem much more likely to shift opinion to "no"--terrorist attacks, further migration crises, and the like seem more likely to trigger a preference for isolation. I don't have a quantitative argument here, so I would call it a coin toss with a slight upgrade for status quo bias.

Embarrassingly, I misread the question the first time I made a prediction. I meant to predict a 40% chance of an EXIT vote! Original reasoning still stands: with polls essentially showing a 50/50 split between those who have decided, and a number of the undecideds being likely to feel compelled to vote, taking into account the evidence for that undecideds tend to favour the status quo on election days, the base case has to be for the UK to remain; however, it is a close call, and, if economic data (which has tended to correlate strongly with polls favouring leaving the EU) worsens for Europe, which you could easily imagine, given its heavy exports and slowing gllobal growth, we could definitely see an exit.

The base rate is about 50%, based on the YouGov survey. The strongest effect in favour of remaining in the EU is that it is the established situation, with less uncertainty about benefits and risks attached. Ups the base rate to about 65-70%. The strongest effect against remaining in the EU is the recency effect for refugee migration. But this effect only works on voters disposed against refugee admission, which is probably a proper subset of all voters. So this effect is smaller than the establishment effect, leading to 55-65%. Taking the mean of this range.

A vote to leave would damage the economy, certainly in the short term and probably in the long run. (As financial markets woke up to the prospect, the pound this week fell to its lowest level against the dollar since 2009.) It would imperil Britain’s security, when threats from terrorists and foreign powers are at their most severe in years. 
 the EU would have a strong incentive to impose a harsh settlement to discourage other countries from leaving. The Brexit camp’s claim that Europe needs Britain more than the other way round is fanciful: the EU takes almost half Britain’s exports, whereas Britain takes less than 10% of the EU’s; and the British trade deficit is mostly with the Germans and Spanish, not with the other 25 countries that would have to agree on a new trade deal.
 Britain outside the EU would be on the sidelines: notionally independent from, but in fact still constrained by, rules it would have no role in formulating. It would be a purer but rather powerless sort of sovereignty.
